verses.text: 失羊的比喻眾稅吏和罪人，都接近耶穌，要聽他講道。

words.note: Refers to the parable of the lost sheep.
Often viewed negatively in biblical times.
Refers to expounding spiritual truths.

verses.text: 法利賽人和經學家，紛紛議論說：「這個人接待罪人，又和他們一起吃飯。」

words.note: A Jewish religious and political group in Jesus' time.
Experts in Jewish law and scripture.

verses.text: 耶穌就對他們講了這個比喻，說：
「你們中間誰有一百隻羊，失去一隻，不把九十九隻留下在曠野，去尋找那失落的，直到找著呢？

words.note: 找著 indicates successful finding.
Used to soften a question or ask 'what about...?'

verses.text: 既找著了，就歡歡喜喜地放在肩上，

words.note: 找著 indicates successful finding.
Reduplicated adverb emphasizing joy.

verses.text: 回到家裡，請朋友鄰舍來，對他們說：『請大家和我一同歡樂，因為我失去的羊已經找到了！』

words.note: A more traditional or biblical term for neighbor.
Often implies spiritual or communal rejoicing in a religious context.

verses.text: 我告訴你們，因為一個罪人悔改，天上也要這樣為他歡樂，比為九十九個不用悔改的義人歡樂更大。

words.note: Refers to the dwelling place of God/angels.
Often implies spiritual or communal rejoicing in a religious context.
Often implies spiritual or communal rejoicing in a religious context.

verses.text: 失銀幣的比喻「或是一個女人，有十個銀幣（「銀幣」原文作「拉克瑪」，一個「拉克瑪」相當於一天的工錢。），失去一個，哪能不點上燈，打掃屋子，細細地找，直到找著呢？

words.note: Used here as a prefix in the title 'Lost Silver Coin Parable'.
Reduplication emphasizes the carefulness.

verses.text: 既找著了，就請朋友鄰舍來，說：『請大家和我一同歡樂，因為我失去的那個銀幣，已經找到了。』

words.note: Often implies 'since this is already the case'.
A more traditional or biblical term for neighbor.
Often implies spiritual or communal rejoicing in a religious context.

verses.text: 我告訴你們，因為一個罪人悔改， 神的使者也必這樣為他歡樂。」

words.note: Refers to God, often capitalized in Christian contexts.
A strong adverb indicating certainty or necessity.
Often implies spiritual or communal rejoicing in a religious context.

verses.text: 浪子的比喻耶穌又說：「某人有兩個兒子。

words.note: Refers to a wasteful or reckless son, specifically in this parable.
A story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson.
Used before measure words, unlike 'èr' (二).
General measure word for people or things.

verses.text: 小兒子對父親說：『爸爸，請把我應得的家業給我。』父親就把財產分給他們兩兄弟。

words.note: Indicates direct object before verb, highlights action's effect.
Indicates a consequence or immediate action.
Used to bring the object before the verb.
Used before measure words.

verses.text: 過了不多幾天，小兒子收拾一切，到遠方去了，在那裡生活放蕩，浪費錢財。

words.note: Indicates completion of an action.
Indicates a change of state or completion of an action.
Describes a lifestyle characterized by excessive indulgence.

verses.text: 他花盡了一切所有的，那地方又遇上了嚴重的饑荒，就窮困起來；

words.note: Resultative complement 盡 indicates complete expenditure.
Indicates completion of an action.
Connects modifier to noun or nominalized phrase.
Indicates completion of an action.
Connects an adjective to a noun.
Often used in religious or historical contexts for food shortages.
Indicates a result or consequence.
Verb complement indicating a new state or a rising tendency.

verses.text: 於是他去投靠當地的一個居民。那人打發他到田裡去放豬，

words.definition: to seek refuge with, rely on
words.note: Implies seeking protection or support from someone.
Connects a modifier to a noun.
General measure word for people or things.
Often used in biblical contexts for sending someone on an errand.
A highly degrading job for a Jew due to pigs being unclean.

verses.text: 他恨不得吃豬所吃的豆莢，可是沒有人給他。

words.note: Lit. 'hate not to get', meaning 'ardently wish'
Particle forming a nominal phrase, indicating the object of a verb
Contextually, pig's food in the parable

verses.text: 他醒悟過來，說：『我父親有那麼多雇工，又有豐富的食物，我卻要在這裡餓死嗎？

words.note: Directional/resultative complement indicating a change of state

verses.text: 我要起來，到我父親那裡去，對他說：爸爸，我得罪了天，也得罪了你，

words.note: Reduplication for intimacy
Used metonymically to refer to God

verses.text: 不配再稱為你的兒子，把我當作一個雇工吧！』

words.note: Introduces direct object before the verb
Indicates suggestion, request, or mild command

verses.text: 於是他起來往父親那裡去。他還在遠處時，他父親看見了他，就動了慈心，跑過去抱著他，連連與他親吻。

words.note: Used as a suffix for clauses indicating 'when'
Directional complement indicating movement past something
More formal than '和'

verses.text: 兒子說：『爸爸，我得罪了天，也得罪了你，不配再稱為你的兒子。』

words.note: Contextually means 'sin against'.
Here, 'Heaven' refers to God.

verses.text: 父親卻吩咐僕人說：『快把那最好的袍子拿來給他穿，把戒指戴在他手上，把鞋穿在他腳上，
把肥牛犢牽來宰了，我們要吃喝快樂，

words.note: Refers to a calf prepared for slaughter, often for celebration.

verses.text: 因為我這兒子是死而復活、失而又得的。』他們就歡樂起來。
「那時，大兒子正在田裡。他回來離家不遠的時候，聽見音樂跳舞的聲音，

words.note: Refers to the elder son in the parable.

verses.text: 就叫了一個僕人來，問他這是怎麼一回事。

words.note: Used frequently in biblical contexts.

verses.text: 僕人說：『你弟弟回來了，你父親因為他平安無恙地回來，就宰了肥牛犢。』

words.note: Used frequently in biblical contexts.
An idiom meaning 'no harm done'.
Often used for killing animals for sacrifice or feast.
Symbolizes a lavish feast in the Bible.

verses.text: 大兒子就生氣，不肯進去；父親出來勸他。
他對父親說：『你看，我服事你這麼多年，從來沒有違背過你的命令，可是你沒有給我一隻山羊羔，叫我和朋友一同歡樂。

words.note: In biblical context, often implies devoted service.

words.definition: from past till now; always (with neg: never)

words.note: Often refers to sacrificial animals in the Bible.
Can be a verb 'to rejoice' or adjective 'joyful'.

verses.text: 但你這個兒子，常常跟娼妓在一起，花盡了你的財產，他一回來，你倒為他宰殺肥牛犢！』

words.note: A term primarily found in historical/literary or religious texts today.
Used with a verb to express 'as soon as...'.
More formal and often refers to killing livestock for food or sacrifice.
Symbolizes a lavish feast in the Bible.

verses.text: 父親對他說：『孩子，你常跟我在一起，我的一切都是你的。
只是因為你這個弟弟是死而復活、失而又得的，我們應該歡喜快樂。』」

words.note: Common biblical phrase for resurrection.
Parallel structure to '死而復活', often used in parables.
